speaker: Mitch
text: Hey Morrie, how are you feeling today?

speaker: Morrie
text: Hello my dear boy. Some days better than others, you know.

speaker: Mitch
text: I've been thinking about our last conversation a lot.

speaker: Morrie
text: Which part stuck with you the most?

speaker: Mitch
text: What you said about success. It's been haunting me.

speaker: Morrie
text: Haunting? That sounds rather dramatic, don't you think?

speaker: Mitch
text: Maybe. But I can't shake the feeling that I've been chasing the wrong things.

speaker: Morrie
text: What do you think you've been chasing?

speaker: Mitch
text: Money, recognition, the next promotion. The usual stuff.

speaker: Morrie
text: And how has that been working out for you?

speaker: Mitch
text: Honestly? I'm more stressed than ever.

speaker: Morrie
text: Stress is the great thief of joy, Mitch.

speaker: Mitch
text: Easy to say when you're not worried about mortgage payments.

speaker: Morrie
text: Ah, so you think I never worried about money?

speaker: Mitch
text: Well... didn't you?

speaker: Morrie
text: Of course I did. But I learned something important along the way.

speaker: Mitch
text: What's that?

speaker: Morrie
text: Money is a tool, not a destination.

speaker: Mitch
text: That sounds like something you'd cross-stitch on a pillow.

speaker: Morrie
text: Ha! You always were a smart aleck.

speaker: Mitch
text: Sorry, I'm just frustrated with everything right now.

speaker: Morrie
text: Tell me what's really bothering you.

speaker: Mitch
text: I feel like I'm running on a treadmill that never stops.

speaker: Morrie
text: So step off the treadmill.

speaker: Mitch
text: It's not that simple, Morrie.

speaker: Morrie
text: Isn't it? What's the worst that could happen?

speaker: Mitch
text: I could lose everything I've worked for.

speaker: Morrie
text: And what exactly have you worked for?

speaker: Mitch
text: A nice house, a good car, financial security...

speaker: Morrie
text: Those are things, not achievements of the heart.

speaker: Mitch
text: The heart doesn't pay bills.

speaker: Morrie
text: But it does pay attention to what matters.

speaker: Mitch
text: I'm not following you.

speaker: Morrie
text: When was the last time you felt truly happy?

speaker: Mitch
text: I don't know... maybe when I got that promotion last year?

speaker: Morrie
text: That lasted how long?

speaker: Mitch
text: A few days, maybe a week.

speaker: Morrie
text: And then what?

speaker: Mitch
text: Then I started worrying about the next one.

speaker: Morrie
text: Do you see the pattern?

speaker: Mitch
text: You're saying I'm on a hamster wheel.

speaker: Morrie
text: I'm saying you're looking for permanent satisfaction in temporary things.

speaker: Mitch
text: So what should I be looking for instead?

speaker: Morrie
text: What brings you peace?

speaker: Mitch
text: I used to love playing music.

speaker: Morrie
text: Used to?

speaker: Mitch
text: I don't have time for that anymore.

speaker: Morrie
text: You don't have time for what brings you peace?

speaker: Mitch
text: When you put it like that, it sounds crazy.

speaker: Morrie
text: It doesn't sound crazy, it sounds human.

speaker: Mitch
text: I've forgotten how to just... be.

speaker: Morrie
text: Being is a practice, like meditation or exercise.

speaker: Mitch
text: How do you practice being?

speaker: Morrie
text: Start with five minutes of doing absolutely nothing.

speaker: Mitch
text: That makes me anxious just thinking about it.

speaker: Morrie
text: That anxiety is exactly what you need to examine.

speaker: Mitch
text: I feel like I'm wasting time if I'm not productive.

speaker: Morrie
text: Who taught you that rest is wasteful?

speaker: Mitch
text: Society? My parents? I don't know.

speaker: Morrie
text: What if rest is actually the most productive thing you can do?

speaker: Mitch
text: That doesn't make sense.

speaker: Morrie
text: A field that's never left fallow eventually stops producing crops.

speaker: Mitch
text: So I'm an overworked field?

speaker: Morrie
text: You're a human being who's forgotten how to tend to himself.

speaker: Mitch
text: This is hard to hear.

speaker: Morrie
text: The truth often is.

speaker: Mitch
text: I don't even know where to start.

speaker: Morrie
text: Start with one small thing that brings you joy.

speaker: Mitch
text: Like what?

speaker: Morrie
text: What did you love as a child?

speaker: Mitch
text: I loved reading stories under my blanket with a flashlight.

speaker: Morrie
text: When did you stop doing that?

speaker: Mitch
text: I guess when I decided it wasn't "adult" enough.

speaker: Morrie
text: What a shame to abandon joy in the name of adulthood.

speaker: Mitch
text: You really think it's that simple?

speaker: Morrie
text: Simple, yes. Easy, no.

speaker: Mitch
text: What's the difference?

speaker: Morrie
text: Simple means uncomplicated. Easy means without effort.

speaker: Mitch
text: So changing my life will take effort.

speaker: Morrie
text: Everything worthwhile does.

speaker: Mitch
text: I'm scared, Morrie.

speaker: Morrie
text: Scared of what?

speaker: Mitch
text: Scared of slowing down and discovering I don't like who I've become.

speaker: Morrie
text: That's the most honest thing you've said today.

speaker: Mitch
text: Great. Now I feel worse.

speaker: Morrie
text: No, now you feel real.

speaker: Mitch
text: What if I've wasted too much time already?

speaker: Morrie
text: Time isn't a bank account that can be overdrawn.

speaker: Mitch
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Morrie
text: Every moment is a new opportunity to choose differently.

speaker: Mitch
text: Even at my age?

speaker: Morrie
text: Especially at your age. You still have so much life ahead of you.

speaker: Mitch
text: Sometimes I feel like it's too late to change.

speaker: Morrie
text: That's fear talking, not wisdom.

speaker: Mitch
text: How do you know the difference?

speaker: Morrie
text: Wisdom whispers possibilities. Fear shouts limitations.

speaker: Mitch
text: I think I've been listening to fear for a long time.

speaker: Morrie
text: What would wisdom tell you right now?

speaker: Mitch
text: Maybe... that it's okay to slow down?

speaker: Morrie
text: What else?

speaker: Mitch
text: That relationships matter more than achievements?

speaker: Morrie
text: Go on.

speaker: Mitch
text: That I don't have to prove my worth through productivity?

speaker: Morrie
text: Now you're starting to understand.

speaker: Mitch
text: It feels scary and liberating at the same time.

speaker: Morrie
text: That's exactly how transformation should feel.

speaker: Mitch
text: Will you help me figure this out?

speaker: Morrie
text: I'm already helping you by asking the right questions.

speaker: Mitch
text: What's the most important question I should ask myself?

speaker: Morrie
text: What kind of person do I want to be remembered as?

speaker: Mitch
text: Not what I want to achieve?

speaker: Morrie
text: Achievements fade. Character endures.

speaker: Mitch
text: I want to be remembered as someone who cared.

speaker: Morrie
text: Then start caring, beginning with yourself.

speaker: Mitch
text: How do I care for myself?

speaker: Morrie
text: The same way you'd care for someone you love deeply.

speaker: Mitch
text: With patience and kindness?

speaker: Morrie
text: And forgiveness for past mistakes.

speaker: Mitch
text: I've been so hard on myself.

speaker: Morrie
text: Self-compassion is not self-indulgence, it's self-preservation.

speaker: Mitch
text: I never thought of it that way.

speaker: Morrie
text: Most people confuse self-care with selfishness.

speaker: Mitch
text: What's the difference?

speaker: Morrie
text: Self-care fills your cup so you can pour into others.

speaker: Mitch
text: I feel like my cup has been empty for years.

speaker: Morrie
text: Then it's time to fill it up again.

speaker: Mitch
text: Thank you, Morrie. This conversation has meant everything to me.

speaker: Morrie
text: Remember, my dear boy, love is the only rational act.

speaker: Mitch
text: I'll remember. I promise.

speaker: Morrie
text: And I'll be here whenever you need to remember who you really are.

speaker: Mitch
text: I love you, old man.

speaker: Morrie
text: I love you too. Now go live like you mean it.
